subject: Entrepreneurship
title: The Scalability Dilemma
description: A 60-second lesson on The Scalability Dilemma.

hook.text: Everyone tells social entrepreneurs to scale. But what works in one village often breaks in the next.

buildup.text: PlayPumps seemed brilliant: merry-go-rounds that pump water while children play. Donors loved it.

discovery.text: When PlayPumps scaled across Africa, reality hit. The pumps needed kids playing constantly to work.

twist.text: In many villages, women ended up pushing the merry-go-rounds themselves. It was harder than a hand pump.

climax.text: PlayPumps spent $16 million and many units were abandoned. Simple hand pumps worked better all along.

punchline.text: Scaling a clever idea is pointless if it doesn't actually work.

quiz.question: Why did PlayPumps fail when they scaled across Africa?
options: Children didn't want to play on the merry-go-rounds
The pumps required constant play to work, and adults ended up pushing them harder than using hand pumps
African governments banned the installation of PlayPumps
